chapter_2_The_java_util_function_Package

Class Recipe_2_2_Suppliers

  • java.lang.Object
    • chapter_2_The_java_util_function_Package.Recipe_2_2_Suppliers

  • public class Recipe_2_2_Suppliers
extends java.lang.Object

    (2.2.) Recipe_2_2_Suppliers


    1. TO DO

      - implement Supplier interface

    2. HOW

      - use a lambda expression or method reference to implement T get() method of the Supplier interface

    3. EQ.

      • useMathRandomAsASupplier() - use Math.random as a Supplier
      • findingANameFromACollection() - finding a name from a Collection

    The implementation consists in providing a method that takes no arguments and returns the generic type.
    There is no requirement that a new or distinct result be returned each time the Supplier is returned. An eq. is Math.random which takes no argument and returns a double. This can be assigned to a Supplier reference and invoked at any time.
    One of the primary use cases for Recipe_2_2_Suppliers is to support the concept of deferred execution - to ensure that a value is retrieved from a Supplier only when appropriate.
    Another example of this is Optional.orElseGet(Supplier) method. Optional is a nonnull object that either wraps a value or is empty. It is typically returned by methods that may reasonably expect to have no result, like finding a value in an empty collection.
    See Also:
    Recipe 3.9. for order, Recipe 5.7. for Logging with a Supplier, Chapter 6 for Optional, Recipes 9.4. - 9.7. for CompletableFuture

      • useMathRandomAsASupplier

        protected static void useMathRandomAsASupplier()
        ◊◊◊ Use Math.random as a Supplier ◊◊◊ 
             // anonymous inner class implementation
     DoubleSupplier randomSupplier = new DoubleSupplier() {
        @Override
        public double getAsDouble() {
            return Math.random();
        }
     };

     // expression lambda
     randomSupplier = () -> Math.random();

     // method reference
     randomSupplier = Math::random;

     System.out.println(randomSupplier.getAsDouble());

      • findingANameFromACollection

        protected static void findingANameFromACollection()
        ◊◊◊ Finding a Name from a Collection ◊◊◊ 
             List<String> names = Arrays.asList("Baaa", "Bbb", "Ccccc", "Cddd", "Eeee");
     Optional<String> first = names.stream().filter(name -> name.startsWith("A")).findFirst();

     System.out.println(first);
     System.out.println(first.orElse("None"));

     // Forms the comma-separated collection, even when name is found
     System.out.println(first.orElse(String.format("No result found in %s",
                                                   names.stream().collect(Collectors.joining(", ")))));

     // Forms the comma-separated collection only if the Optional is empty
     System.out.println(first.orElseGet(() -> String.format("No result found in %s",
                                                            names.stream().collect(Collectors.joining(", ")))));
        It is possible to apply a filter so there are no elements remaining in the stream, so the method returns an Optional. That Optional contains the desired element, or is empty.

        The Optional.orElse(Object) method is processed even if the value is found in the Optional. It is ok to use it if the default is a simple string, but can be wasteful if processing is necessary to return a value.
        The Optional.orElseGet(Supplier) takes a Supplier as an argument. The advantage is that the Supplier.get() method will only be invoked when the Optional is empty.

        Other examples:
        • Optional.orElseThrow(Supplier) takes a Supplier<X extends Exception> - only executed if an exception occurs
        • Objects.requireNonNull(Object, Supplier) - it customizes its response only if the first argument is null
        • CompletableFuture.supplyAsync(Supplier) - returns a CompletableFuture that is asynchronously completed by a task running with the value obtained by calling the given Supplier
        • Logger class has overloads for all its logging methods that take a Supplier<String> rather than just a string
        See Also:
        Recipe 3.9. for order, Chapter 6 for Optional, Recipes 9.4. - 9.7. for CompletableFuture
